articles.headline: Harder-Edged Warnings About Britain’s Economy
articles.snippet: Britain’s deteriorating public finances may require the government to seek International Monetary Fund aid.
articles.abstract: Britain’s deteriorating public finances may require the government to seek International Monetary Fund aid.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  In the dank gloom of the factory that he and his fellow workers had just occupied, John Horscroft recalled a time 30 years ago when strikes and industrial unrest in Britain were an everyday occurrence.

articles.headline: In Recruiting an Afghan Militia, U.S. Faces a Test
articles.snippet: An effort to transplant a program that succeeded in Iraq reflects the difficulties facing Americans as they try to make gains in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: An effort to transplant a program that succeeded in Iraq reflects the difficulties facing Americans as they try to make gains in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAIDAN SHAHR, Afghanistan  The ambitious American plan to arm local militias in villages across the country was coming down to a single moment.

articles.headline: U.S. Stymied as Guns Flow to Mexican Cartels
articles.snippet: Violent crime groups in Mexico are seen as capitalizing on the ease of acquiring American weapons.
articles.abstract: Violent crime groups in Mexico are seen as capitalizing on the ease of acquiring American weapons.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  John Phillip Hernandez, a 24-year-old unemployed machinist who lived with his parents, walked into a giant sporting goods store here in July 2006, and plunked $2,600 in cash on a glass display counter. A few minutes later, Mr. Hernandez walked out with three military-style rifles.

articles.headline: As Pills Treat Cancer, Insurance Lags Behind
articles.snippet: Pills are the new wave in cancer treatment, but payment coverage is often behind the times.
articles.abstract: Pills are the new wave in cancer treatment, but payment coverage is often behind the times.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chuck Stauffer’s insurance covered the surgery to remove his brain tumor. It covered his brain scans. And it would have paid fully for tens of thousands of dollars of intravenous chemotherapy at a doctor’s office or hospital.

articles.headline: U.S. Planning to Reveal Data on Health of Top Banks
articles.snippet: As it tries to restore confidence in the financial system, the Obama administration is preparing to disclose the conditions of the 19 biggest banks in the country.
articles.abstract: As it tries to restore confidence in the financial system, the Obama administration is preparing to disclose the conditions of the 19 biggest banks in the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is drawing up plans to disclose the conditions of the 19 biggest banks in the country, according to senior administration officials, as it tries to restore confidence in the financial system without unnerving investors.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Eric Dash

articles.headline: U.S. Program Lends a Hand to Banks, Quietly
articles.snippet: Some banks, including Goldman Sachs, are quietly holding on to a government subsidy that allows them to issue debt cheaply with the backing of the F.D.I.C.
articles.abstract: Some banks, including Goldman Sachs, are quietly holding on to a government subsidy that allows them to issue debt cheaply with the backing of the F.D.I.C.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eager to escape the long arm of government, Goldman Sachs is preparing to return $10 billion in taxpayer funds as fast as the ink can dry on the check. But the bank, and a number of others, is quietly holding on to other forms of public support that come with virtually no strings attached.

articles.headline: At an Age for Music and Dreams, Real Life Intrudes
articles.snippet: Tiffany Clay, 18, is the top violinist at her high school in Ohio, but her dreams are bound by money worries.
articles.abstract: Tiffany Clay, 18, is the top violinist at her high school in Ohio, but her dreams are bound by money worries.

articles.headline: Public Pension Managers Rethink Hedge Fund Ties
articles.snippet: Some public pension funds have suffered losses along with the hedge fund industry’s fortunes.
articles.abstract: Some public pension funds have suffered losses along with the hedge fund industry’s fortunes.
articles.lead_paragraph: From New York to California, public pension funds staked billions in good times on the highest of Wall Street high rollers: hedge fund managers and corporate buyout specialists.

articles.headline: Hedge Fund Executive Guilty of Securities Fraud
articles.snippet: Barrett Wissman is the first investment executive to be implicated in an investigation of corruption at the New York state pension fund.
articles.abstract: Barrett Wissman is the first investment executive to be implicated in an investigation of corruption at the New York state pension fund.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALBANY  A hedge fund executive has pleaded guilty to securities fraud and is cooperating with New York State Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo’s investigation of corruption at the state pension fund, according to court records unsealed in Manhattan on Tuesday.

articles.headline: Afghan Women Protest New Law on Home Life
articles.snippet: Three hundred women in Kabul demanded the repeal of a Taliban-like law that permits, among other things, marital rape.
articles.abstract: Three hundred women in Kabul demanded the repeal of a Taliban-like law that permits, among other things, marital rape.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  The young women stepped off the bus and moved toward the protest march just beginning on the other side of the street when they were spotted by a mob of men.
